FacilityName: Publix Super Markets, Inc. Orlando Refrigerated DC

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Water Dilution Tank for ammonia relief

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Publix Super Markets, Inc. (Publix) Orlando Refrigerated Distribution Center (RDC) is located at 7350 Hazeltine National Drive, Orlando, Orange County, Florida. Publix requires each facility to develop and maintain accident prevention programs and an emergency response plan appropriate to the site. Each site is also responsible for regulatory compliance issues that apply to the site. A site PSM Coordinator is appointed to facilitate compliance. Publix' corporate and division environmental and safety personnel provide assistance in training for site employees and in budgeting and procurement of the safety and training services.

2. Facility and Regulated Substances Handled
The Orlando RDC is located on Hazeltine National Drive, north of the FL-528 and the Orlando International Airport. The Distribution warehouse consists of areas for dry, frozen and cooler storage of non-perishable and perishable items for distribution to the Publix Super Markets. The facility includes a freezer with an Automated Storage and Retrieval System (ASRS). To provide cooling to these areas, the facility uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant in quantities above 10,000 pounds. The refrigeration equipment is located within a dedicated engine room; emergency relief is to a diffusion water tank.

3. Prevention Program
The facility exceeds the ammonia threshold quantity for OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, 1910.119, and the process is therefore subject to PSM requirements. For RMP compliance purposes, this places the refrigeration process in the Program 3 level. The facility will use its PSM program as the required Program 3 Prevention Program. The Orlando DC has a program in place to comply with the OSHA PSM Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119. It includes a preventive maintenance plan which requires all ammonia refrigeration equipment to be periodically inspected and serviced. This will ensure that equipment remains in

good operating condition and will minimize the probability of accidents due to faulty equipment. The program implemented at Orlando mirrors programs in place at other Publix ammonia refrigerated facilities. In developing the PSM program, the Orlando facility also developed written operating procedures for the refrigeration process. These procedures cover all phases of operation and include information on safety devices. These procedures are used to train all operators and mechanics who work on the ammonia refrigeration processes to ensure consistency of operation and minimize human error. These measures ensure that all refrigeration operators and mechanics are properly trained. Publix has also implemented safe work practices and procedures such as lockout/tagout and hot work permitting to ensure that all nonroutine work can be performed safely. Other components of the prevention program include collection and periodic review of all equipment information, including Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs). The staff ensures that if equipment design deficiencies are identified that they are corrected. These actions will ensure that equipment meets all refrigeration industry standards, and that accurate equipment information will be available when needed. To ensure that Orlando RDC's refrigeration staff has the skill necessary to identify unsafe conditions, they are included in a refrigeration training program and receive support from refrigeration staff at Publix facility in nearby Lakeland, Florida. Training includes Process Hazard Analyses, Operating Procedures, Maintenance Procedures, Emergency Response, and Safe Work Practices. The ammonia refrigeration staff, with the assistance of a consultant, performed a PHA of the process in April 2014 prior to startup, a revalidation PHA in 2019, and more recently, a revalidation of the PHA in 2024. Additional PSM procedures, including Management of Change, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Compliance Audits, and Incident Inves

tigation also ensure the continued safe operation and prompt correction of deficiencies. The PSM Program receives the full support of facility management and involvement of employees at all levels.

4. Five-year Accident History
The Orlando RDC has had no accidental releases meeting the reporting criteria in the past five years.

5. Emergency Response Program
The Orlando RDC has a written Emergency Response Plan for ammonia in place. The program complies with 29 CFR 1910.38. The facility also has internal emergency response capability and has developed a program to comply with paragraph (q) of 29 CFR 1910.120. The current plan has been coordinated with local responders. Notification is made locally by dialing 911 or contacting the Florida State Warning Point at (800) 320-0519.

6. Plans to Improve Safety
To improve safety, tabletop and dress out exercises are being performed with the fire department at least once a year. Publix continues to monitor industry regulations to enhance safe operation of the process.
